title: A Pilot Electroencephalography (EEG) Study to Evaluate the Effect of CT1812 Treatment on Synaptic Activity in Subjects With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This is a single-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 29-day, 2-period crossover Phase 2 study of 1 dose level of CT1812 (active) or placebo in adults with mild to moderate AD.
description_detailed:
This is a single-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 29-day, 2-period crossover Phase 2 study of 1 dose level of CT1812 (active) or placebo in adults with mild to moderate AD.

16 participants (8 randomized to 300 mg CT1812, 8 randomly assigned to placebo during each treatment period): the 8 participants randomly assigned to CT1812 in Treatment Period 1 will receive placebo in Treatment Period 2; the 8 participants randomly assigned to placebo in Treatment Period 1 will receive CT1812 in Treatment Period 2.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails:
This was a single-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 2 period, crossover, Phase 2 study.

Eligible participants were randomly assigned to receive either 300 mg/day CT1812 in Period 1 and placebo in Period 2, or placebo in Period 1 and 300 mg/day CT1812 in Period 2 after a washout period of 14 days. The duration of each period was 29 days. A total of 16 participants were randomized and 15 participants completed the study.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: The study was conducted at a single site in the Netherlands.

groups.title: First Placebo Non-active Study Drug, Then Active Treatment With CT1812 at a Dose of 300mg
groups.description: CT1812 was provided to participants as two hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC) capsules each containing 150 mg of CT1812. Matching placebo capsules containing lactose monohydrate were provided. CT1812 or matching placebo capsules were to be administered orally as a single daily dose for 29 days. Each dose CT1812 or matching placebo consisted of 2 capsules. All participants ingested the first dose at the study site and were observed for 2 hours. Capsules were swallowed with approximately 240 mL of water with or without food.

groups.title: First Active Treatment With CT1812 at a Dose of 300mg, Then Placebo Non-active Study Drug
groups.description: CT1812 was provided to participants as two hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC) capsules each containing 150 mg of CT1812. Matching placebo capsules containing lactose monohydrate were provided. CT1812 or matching placebo capsules were to be administered orally as a single daily dose for 29 days. Each dose CT1812 or matching placebo consisted of 2 capsules. All participants ingested the first dose at the study site and were observed for 2 hours. Capsules were swallowed with approximately 240 mL of water with or without food.

achievements.comment: Fifteen participants completed Period 2. Participant 3001-0031 (CT1812/placebo) withdrew consent before Period 2.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of TEAEs, Related TEAEs, SAEs, and Related SAEs
outcomeMeasures.description: Adverse events were captured from the start of study-related procedures at Visit 1 (including diagnostic assessments or signing of ICF) onward during the course of this study. Adverse events were coded using MedDRA Version 22.0
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: A total of 16 participants were randomized and completed Period 1. Fifteen participants completed Period 2. Participant 3001-0031 (CT1812/placebo) withdrew consent before Period 2. A total of 15 participants completed the study as planned.

groups.title: CT1812
groups.description: Active Treatment- CT1812 at a dose of 300mg

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in the Brain Activity Reflected by Changes of Spectral Power in Conventional Frequency Bands Measured by the Global Relative Theta (4-8 Hz) Power Obtained Through EEG Assessment.
outcomeMeasures.description: Global relative theta power was quantified and summarized descriptively (observed values, change from the pre-treatment values) by treatment and time point using the Safety Population. The change from period baseline in global relative theta power within each period was analyzed using a linear mixed model with fixed effects for treatment group (CT1812 or placebo), sequence, and period, and a random effect for subject within sequence. The analysis was conducted using PROC MIXED. The ability of CT1812 to rapidly restore synapse number to normal was expected to result in a decrease in EEG theta power in AD patients in response to short-term treatment with CT1812. Thus, a decrease in the Global Relative Theta Power represents better outcomes, while high values in the Global Relative Theta Power represent worse outcomes. The unit is represented by uV\^2/Hz (microvolt squared per frequency). This is a common unit for spectral power density, and how relative power measures are displayed.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Up to 16 participants were planned to be enrolled. A total of 16 participants were randomized and completed Period 1. Fifteen participants completed Period 2. Participant 3001-0031 (CT1812/placebo) withdrew consent before Period 2. A total of 15 participants completed the study as planned.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Day 1 through Day 29 of Period 1 and Day 1 (study day 44) and Day 29 (study day 72) of Period 2

groups.title: CT1812
groups.description: Active Treatment- CT1812 at a dose of 300mg/Placebo

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Predose CT1812 Plasma Concentrations.
outcomeMeasures.description: For the measurements of pre-dose and post-dose plasma concentrations of CT1812, samples were collected 1± 0.25 hour predose. Single concentrations of CT1812 at selected predose and post-dose time points were reported.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The pharmacokinetic (PK) population was comprised of all randomized participants who received at least one dose of study drug and had at least one PK concentration of CT1812. All 16 randomized participants were included in the PK Population.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline through Day 84: Pre and Post- Dose on Days 1, 29 AND Pre Dose Days 8, 15, 22.

groups.description: All 16 randomized participants were included in the PK Population.

pointOfContact.title: Chief Medical Officer, Head of R&D

drug: CT1812 (Elayta) — a brain‑penetrant small‑molecule sigma‑2 receptor (TMEM97) antagonist that displaces amyloid‑beta (Aβ) oligomers from neuronal synapses
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests CT1812 in people with mild–moderate AD and the published literature describes CT1812 as a brain‑penetrant small molecule that binds/modulates the sigma‑2 receptor (TMEM97) and acts to prevent/displace toxic Aβ oligomers from synaptic receptors — i.e., it targets AD pathology (disease‑modifying mechanism). citeturn0search3turn0search5.

Act: Key extracted trial details — single‑site, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, 29‑day, 2‑period crossover Phase 2; primary readout here is EEG (qEEG) to evaluate synaptic activity after CT1812 treatment, consistent with a proof‑of‑mechanism, synaptoprotective intervention rather than a purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search1turn0search2.

Reflect: Classification — 'disease‑targeted small molecule' — follows from CT1812 being a small‑molecule sigma‑2 receptor antagonist that displaces Aβ oligomers and aims to protect/restore synapses (targeting underlying pathology). It is not a biologic (no antibody/vaccine), not described as a general symptomatic cognitive enhancer, nor an agent aimed at neuropsychiatric symptoms. Remaining uncertainty: the brief 29‑day EEG study is a short proof‑of‑mechanism window and not a full efficacy trial, but that does not change the drug class or intended pathology‑targeting mechanism. citeturn0search3turn0search1.

Web search sources used (selected): PubMed phase1/2 and mechanism reviews (CT1812 binds/modulates sigma‑2 receptor and displaces Aβ oligomers). citeturn0search4turn0search3. Additional clinical biomarker and EEG pilot reports used: JPAD EEG pilot description and Alzheimer’s Research & Therapy synaptic PET/biomarker study. citeturn0search1turn0search2.
explanation_agent: Reason: CT1812 (Elayta) is a brain‑penetrant, disease‑targeted small molecule that binds/modulates the sigma‑2 receptor (TMEM97) and acts to prevent and displace toxic Aβ oligomers from neuronal synapses — i.e., the drug’s intended mechanism is to reduce soluble amyloid‑beta oligomer–mediated synaptotoxicity, which maps to the CADRO amyloid‑beta category. citeturn0search6turn0search3

Act: Key trial details extracted — randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, ~29‑day crossover Phase 2 EEG (qEEG) study measuring synaptic activity; CT1812 is described in preclinical and clinical literature as a σ‑2/TMEM97 antagonist that displaces Aβ oligomers to CSF and normalizes synaptic/EEG measures — these facts support classification under Amyloid beta rather than a purely symptomatic or unrelated target. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search5

Reflect: Classification check — the intervention’s primary, disease‑modifying mechanism is removal/displacement of soluble Aβ oligomers (not primarily tau, inflammation, neurotransmitter receptors, etc.), so the most specific CADRO match is A) Amyloid beta. Although the molecular binding site is sigma‑2/TMEM97, that action is used to modulate Aβ oligomer binding at synapses, so this is not best classified under ‘Other’ or a non‑amyloid CADRO category. Remaining uncertainty is limited (short electrophysiology proof‑of‑mechanism study), but it does not change the drug’s amyloid‑targeting mechanism. citeturn0search3turn0search6

Web search sources (selected) used to support the above: (1) PubMed / JPAD report of the 29‑day qEEG pilot showing EEG normalization with CT1812 in mild‑moderate AD. citeturn0search0turn0search1; (2) Systematic review summarizing clinical data and mechanism that CT1812 is a σ‑2/TMEM97 antagonist which can displace Aβ oligomers. citeturn0search3; (3) JAD/preclinical and review articles describing the σ‑2/TMEM97 binding, displacement of Aβ oligomers, and synaptoprotective rationale for CT1812. citeturn0search5turn0search6; (4) Phase 1/2 biomarker study (SV2A PET, FDG PET) and other clinical biomarker reports referenced in reviews. citeturn0search4
